description: Borrowed from Latin congratulor, congratulatus, from gratus (“blessing”).

verbs.description: congratulate (third-person singular simple present congratulates, present participle congratulating, simple past and past participle congratulated)

entries.meaning: To express one’s sympathetic pleasure or joy to the person(s) it is felt for.
examples: Remind me to congratulate Dave and Lisa on their wedding.
We must congratulate Dave and Lisa on getting married.

entries.meaning: (reflexive) To consider oneself fortunate in some matter.
examples: I congratulated myself on the success of my plan.
